content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see multiple fragments of fibrofatty tissue. Within this tissue, there are several (approximately 6-7) well-defined, basophilic (dark purple) nodules that are consistent with lymph nodes. The goal is to examine each of these nodes for evidence of cancer spread.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area because it represents one of the distinct lymph nodes, specifically the first one on the far left. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine each lymph node identified at low power to assess for the presence of metastatic tumor cells. This is a standard part of the cancer staging process. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically screening all potential lymph nodes on the slide. The highlighted area corresponds to the first lymph node on the far left of the tissue fragments. Zooming in is necessary to evaluate the architecture and cellular composition of the node at high magnification to determine if it is benign/reactive or if it contains metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist evaluating a colorectal cancer case, a critical part of the staging (N stage) is the meticulous examination of all harvested lymph nodes for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed over the first lymph node from the left. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic review of each lymph node to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high magnification, specifically looking for infiltrating nests of malignant glandular cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is a clearly identifiable lymph node, located on the top left of the slide. When evaluating a case for staging, it is crucial to systematically examine every lymph node. This appears to be the first lymph node in a logical sequence of review. At low power, it is densely cellular and basophilic, which requires high-power examination to differentiate between a reactive lymph node and a node replaced by tumor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to identify all lymph nodes and examine them for metastatic cancer to determine the N stage. The green box is placed over a distinct, well-circumscribed, basophilic nodule located in the uppermost part of the tissue fragment on the far left. This is clearly a lymph node, and it is standard practice to systematically examine every single lymph node at high magnification. I am zooming into this first lymph node to begin my detailed assessment for the presence of tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to systematically evaluate every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The area highlighted by the green box is clearly one of the lymph nodes. I would zoom into this area, and every other lymph node, to assess its architecture at high magnification. The goal is to look for atypical cells, abnormal glandular structures, or other features that would indicate the presence of metastatic colorectal cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the task is to screen all submitted lymph nodes for metastatic disease. The area indicated by the green box is centered on one of the well-defined, basophilic structures that is clearly a lymph node. I would systematically examine each of these lymph nodes at higher magnification. This particular node, the second large one from the left in the upper cluster, is a prime target for detailed inspection to confirm it is a lymph node and to search for the presence of any atypical or malignant cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining all the lymph nodes present on the slide. The area indicated by the green box corresponds to one of the larger and more densely cellular lymph nodes. It is crucial to examine such nodes at high magnification to assess their architecture, look for any foreign cell populations (like metastatic carcinoma), and check for effacement of the normal lymphoid structure or capsular invasion. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is clearly a lymph node, but its architecture is not uniform. Instead of being entirely composed of dense lymphoid tissue (dark purple), it shows a mottled appearance with lighter, more eosinophilic (pinkish) and irregularly basophilic areas. This heterogeneity is highly suspicious for effacement of the normal lymph node structure by an infiltrating process, most likely metastatic carcinoma. The goal is to examine this suspicious area at high magnification to confirm the presence or absence of tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is part of the systematic examination of all the submitted tissue. While not a well-circumscribed lymph node, this area in the fibrofatty tissue appears subtly more cellular and fibrotic than the surrounding adipose tissue. It is crucial to examine such areas carefully to look for small, isolated tumor nodules (tumor deposits), which are prognostically significant and affect the N stage (specifically, the N1c category if no lymph nodes are positive). I am also looking for other adverse features like lymphovascular or perineural invasion, which can be found in the pericolic fat away from obvious nodes. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, it is standard practice to examine every single lymph node identified in a cancer resection specimen to accurately determine the N (node) stage. The area highlighted by the green box contains one of these distinct, ovoid, basophilic structures consistent with a lymph node. I am zooming into this specific node, which is the rightmost one on the slide, as part of the systematic evaluation of all submitted lymph nodes. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The green box is centered on one of the basophilic nodules identified in the thumbnail view. As a pathologist evaluating a colorectal cancer case, the standard procedure is to systematically examine every single lymph node to check for metastasis, as this is a critical component of cancer staging (the 'N' in TNM staging). I am zooming into this specific nodule, one of the more centrally located ones, to examine its cellular composition at high magnification and determine if it is a benign (negative) lymph node or if it contains metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I am systematically screening each lymph node present in the specimen. The green box is centered on one of these lymph nodes. I am zooming in to carefully examine the architecture of the node, particularly the subcapsular sinus and the perinodal fat. This area is a common site for the initial deposition of metastatic tumor cells, so a high-power examination is crucial to rule out or confirm the presence of metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The zoom area is located adjacent to a large lymph node in the bottom-right tissue fragment. At low power, this specific spot shows a small, dense, cellular focus within the perinodal fat, which is distinct from the main body of the lymph node. Such a finding is highly suspicious and requires high-magnification review to rule out or confirm critical staging features such as extranodal tumor extension, a satellite tumor deposit, perineural invasion (PNI), or lymphovascular invasion (LVI). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see lymphoid tissue characterized by a dense population of small, dark lymphocytes. This tissue is adjacent to mature adipose tissue (fat cells). I do not see any atypical cells, irregular glands, or nests of malignant cells that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is that it shows a benign (reactive) lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the typical architecture of a lymph node. There are well-defined lymphoid follicles, some with paler germinal centers, surrounded by darker mantle zones. The predominant cell type is a dense population of small, round lymphocytes. I do not see any atypical cells, glandular structures, or nests of malignant epithelial cells that would indicate metastasis. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a dense and monotonous population of small, dark lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. A striking feature is the presence of numerous eosinophilic (pink), hyalinized, and acellular structures which represent atrophic or 'burnt-out' germinal centers. The overall architecture is effaced by the lymphoid proliferation. There are no identifiable metastatic tumor cells, such as atypical glands or nests of pleomorphic epithelial cells. My impression is that this is a lymph node showing reactive changes, specifically marked follicular regression and hyalinization. There is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in this field of view, so this part of the lymph node is considered negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a dense and monotonous population of small, round cells with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. These lymphocytes are arranged in diffuse sheets and are infiltrating surrounding tissues, including some pink, striated skeletal muscle fibers and adipose tissue. I do not see any atypical cells, malignant glands, or necrotic areas that would suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a lymph node that is negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a dense, diffuse population of small, round cells with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. This is the parenchyma of a lymph node. The surrounding tissue at the bottom of the image is perinodal adipose tissue (fat cells) and fibrous stroma with small blood vessels. I do not see any atypical glandular structures, nests of malignant cells, or individual cells with large pleomorphic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression of this specific area is that it shows a benign, reactive lymph node, which is negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the parenchyma of a lymph node. The most striking features are several well-formed, non-necrotizing granulomas, which are composed of epithelioid histiocytes and occasional multinucleated giant cells, surrounded by a cuff of lymphocytes. The background lymphoid tissue appears reactive. I do not see any atypical glands, nests of malignant epithelial cells, or extensive necrosis to suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node with prominent granulomatous inflammation. This node is negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, there is a clear demarcation between two types of tissue. The upper portion of the image shows residual lymph node tissue, characterized by dense sheets of small, dark lymphocytes. The lower, larger portion of the image is infiltrated by malignant glandular structures. These are irregular, crowded, and back-to-back glands composed of atypical epithelial cells with large, hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei. This morphology is classic for adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a lymph node with extensive metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming it as a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

At this higher magnification, I see the edge of a lymph node. The majority of the field shows a dense, monotonous sheet of small lymphocytes, consistent with lymphoid parenchyma. The node is surrounded by a fibrous capsule and perinodal adipose tissue. The most important finding is at the very bottom right corner, where a small focus of atypical glandular structures is present. These glands are composed of malignant epithelial cells, characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

At high magnification, this area shows unequivocal features of metastatic adenocarcinoma. There are numerous, poorly-formed, and back-to-back malignant glands infiltrating a desmoplastic stroma. The tumor cells exhibit significant nuclear atypia, including hyperchromasia, irregular nuclear contours, and prominent nucleoli. Some glandular lumens contain necrotic debris ("dirty necrosis"). In the upper left corner, there is a rim of residual, dense lymphoid tissue, confirming that this is indeed a lymph node. My impression is metastatic adenocarcinoma within a lymph node, making this a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 10. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see adipose tissue and a significant amount of desmoplastic stroma (pink fibrous tissue). The key finding is the presence of atypical epithelial cells floating within pools of extracellular mucin (the pale, acellular background). These cells are arranged in small, irregular clusters and cords. The cells themselves have enlarged, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. This morphology is diagnostic of a tumor deposit of metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma within the fibrofatty tissue. This is not a lymph node, but rather a focus of metastasis in the soft tissue.
This is ROI 11 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a lymph node partially replaced by atypical cells. On the right, there is a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes, characteristic of a lymph node. However, within this lymphoid tissue, there are irregular, infiltrating nests and clusters of malignant epithelial cells. These cells have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm and large, irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei, forming poorly-defined glandular structures. This is a classic appearance of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 12 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a collection of lymphoid cells (the small dark purple cells) surrounded by and infiltrated by mature adipose tissue (the large, clear, circular spaces). This is a lymph node with marked fatty infiltration, a common benign finding. The lymphoid cells appear to be a mixed population of small lymphocytes without significant atypia. I do not see any clusters of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or large pleomorphic cells that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression of this specific field is a benign (negative for malignancy) lymph node with fatty replacement.
This is ROI 13 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows the edge of a lymph node. On the right, there is a dense population of small, dark, uniform lymphocytes, characteristic of a benign lymph node cortex. In the center is the pink, fibrous lymph node capsule. To the left, in the perinodal tissue, there is adipose tissue (fat cells), some edematous stroma, and a significant amount of fresh hemorrhage (red blood cells). Crucially, in this specific field of view, there are no visible nests of atypical epithelial cells or glandular structures to suggest metastatic carcinoma. My impression for this specific area is a benign lymph node (negative for malignancy) with associated perinodal hemorrhage, which may be related to the surgical procedure.
This is ROI 14 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a large vessel, likely a vein, which is surrounded by a dense cuff of lymphocytes (perivascular inflammation). Crucially, within the lumen of this vessel, there is a large, dark, disorganized cluster of atypical cells. These cells have large, irregular nuclei and are clustered together, which is characteristic of a tumor embolus. Red blood cells are also visible within the vessel. My impression is definitive lymphovascular invasion (LVI), which is a significant prognostic factor indicating the tumor has invaded the vascular system.
